summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Robert W. Sweet, requesting a limited order to unseal civil discovery materials held by the law firm Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP. The materials are sought via a grand jury subpoena for an ongoing investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and others for sex trafficking and enticement of minors. The filing argues that the protective order in the civil litigation should be modified to allow compliance with the subpoena.

persons.name: Robert W. Sweet
persons.context: The judge presiding over the request to unseal civil discovery materials related to the Epstein investigation. The letter is addressed to him.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as a subject of an ongoing grand jury investigation for possible violations of federal sex trafficking and enticement statutes.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Named as a defendant in the underlying civil litigation (Giuffre v. Maxwell, et al.) from which discovery materials are being sought.

connections.description: Both are implicated in the same investigation into sex trafficking of minors, with Maxwell being a defendant in the related civil litigation.

events.title: Issuance of Grand Jury Subpoena
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office served a grand jury subpoena on the law firm Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP for discovery materials from the civil case Giuffre v. Maxwell, et al.

events.title: Government's Application to Unseal
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office filed this application requesting the court modify a protective order to allow the law firm to comply with the grand jury subpoena.

locations: United States Courthouse, New York, New York 10007
The Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office was conducting an active, non-public grand jury investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and others for sex trafficking and enticement of minors as of February 2019.
The investigation sought discovery materials from the sealed civil lawsuit Giuffre v. Maxwell, et al., which were held by the plaintiffs' law firm, Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP.
The law firm was willing to comply with the grand jury subpoena but felt constrained by a protective order from the civil case, prompting the government's court application.
The government argued that protecting parties from 'embarrassment' is not a valid reason to withhold information from a legitimate law enforcement investigation into serious crimes.
The filing reveals the government's strategic concern about alerting investigation targets (Epstein and others), which could lead to evidence destruction or flight.
